185162395.review:
Broken Sword: The Shadow of the Templars is a game that I wanted to love, especially given its reputation as a classic in the point-and-click adventure genre. 
However, my experience with this title was ultimately underwhelming, and I suspect part of the blame lies in the fact that I played its sequel, Broken Sword II: The Smoking Mirror, first. 
While the second game captivated me with its pacing, humor, and engaging puzzles, returning to the original felt like a step backward.
While the plot is intriguing on paper, its execution left me cold... 
The pacing felt sluggish, and the frequent exposition dumps made the narrative feel more like a history lecture than a thrilling mystery! 
Compared to the snappier dialogue and more dynamic plot of the second game, this entry struggled to hold my attention.
Gameplay is another area where the game shows its age. 
The puzzles, while occasionally clever, often rely on obtuse logic that can frustrate even seasoned adventure game players! 
There were moments where I found myself aimlessly clicking on every object in the environment, hoping for some breakthrough... 
In contrast, the puzzles in the sequel felt more intuitive and rewarding, striking a better balance between challenge and playability!
The visuals and art direction are undeniably charming, with hand-drawn backgrounds that evoke a sense of nostalgia. 
However, the animations and character models lack the polish and fluidity seen in The Smoking Mirror. 
One of the most noticeable drawbacks is the pacing. 
The game takes its time introducing characters and settings, which can be appreciated by players who enjoy slower storytelling. 
However, having already experienced the more tightly structured sequel, I found the original’s deliberate pace to be tedious and lacking urgency.
It’s not all bad, of course. 
The Shadow of the Templars deserves credit for laying the groundwork for the series and introducing characters that would go on to shine in later installments. 
The Parisian atmosphere is beautifully realized, and the score complements the game’s tone perfectly. 
Yet, these strengths weren’t enough to outweigh my frustrations.
Ultimately, my experience with Broken Sword: The Shadow of the Templars was hampered by my exposure to its sequel, which I found to be a more refined and enjoyable experience!
While I can appreciate its historical significance and the role it played in shaping the adventure genre, playing it after The Smoking Mirror highlighted its shortcomings in a way that might not have been as glaring otherwise. 
For those new to the series, I would recommend starting here to fully appreciate its legacy, but for me, it was a disappointing revisit to a classic that didn’t live up to its reputation.
